body.head: THE MINER'S SONG.

lg.l: We left the grassy paths where oft we used to roam,
We left the mournful lake where oft we used to sail,
We left the mother dear in our far away home.
We came out here with hope, we came perhaps to fail.
Four in our eyes then shone the unholy lust of gold;
We longed to go back rich, back to our home again,
Back to the lone farm-yard, back to the lowing fold,
And back to her we love who waits perhaps in vain.
But as we work and work, fades in our eyes the lust,
And now that we succeed we do not laugh, but groan;
As we wash in the stream the precious golden dust,
And as our pick strikes fire out of the sullen stone.
But we will not return as poor as we came here;
We are too proud for that and home we will not go
To see those that were friends contemptuously sneer,
And speak to us with mock and with insulting woe.
Throw wealth away, my men; be happy if you can,
But to not seek to find your happiness in gold.
Ambitious ever was, and shall be, heart of man
Till in the grave he lie as powerless as cold.
Oh! had we stay'd at home; for our eyes do not greet
The few handfuls of gold we may find now and then,
For they are but the mud we tramp under our feet,
When compared to joy, the real wealth of men.
As we direct our steps to that familiar stream,
As the well-known pick-axe with trembling hands we ply,
Our hearts are dark as night on which sun will ne'er beam;
We work and work to live, though we ask God to die.
And as our pick-axe meets the sullen rocks near by,
As the river tears past with a terrific roar
The distant waterfall seems mournfully to sigh
And echo dull for us seems but to sigh the more.
As with the pick and shovel we turn the heated sod,
As our minds go back to th' old home with a pang,
We ask the Being we worship, the great merciful God,
The Maori to send with his red boomerang.

body.l: Next week I shall make an interesting announcement to my readers who are fond of puzzles.

lg.l: I hear in the Moon:—
That the municipal year is drawing to a close.
That there is speculation as to candidates for the respective wards.
That preparations are actively proceeding for the Mayor's ball next Friday.
That the children will have a good time.
That there will be many attractive costumes.
That there is much talk at the Point regarding an alleged bit of sharp practice.
That a certain captain has found it out to his cost.
That presentations are a frequent ocurrence on the railway.
That two made this week were well deserved.
That there were certainly no black looks when subscriptions were asked for one of them.
That Australians will be well represented in South Africa if the present rate of immigration continues.
That, though the Ethiopian cannot change his colour, he had spots knocked off him at the Missionary Conference.
That three different heads — King, President, and Pope — have absorbed much attention this week.
That La Belle France's encouragement of John Bull's overtures will result in happy union of interest.
That "hope told a flattering tale" as to the disappearance of plague.
That it will require a long absence of cases to justify belief in permanent clearance.
That added interest is given to the approaching Natal tennis championships as the result of the play at Mitchell Park last Saturday
That to-night's concert will be well worth attending.
That Geo. Walton's Company expect a crowd to see them "In Gay Paree."
